Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of a Simulation-Based Curriculum for Open Vascular Surgical Skills

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised into two groups

Participants.evidence: Second-year surgery residents were eligible to participate. Participants were randomised into two groups

Intervention.evidence: the intervention group received a six-session open vascular skills curriculum, while the control group received standard training

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates a simulation-based curriculum designed to address this training gap

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the improvement in technical skills, measured using the Objective Structured Assessment of Technical Skills (OSATS) form during the fifth and sixth sessions

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not feasible due to the nature of the intervention

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 101 residents were randomised, with 50 in the intervention group and 51 in the control group

Number_Analysed.evidence: The analysis was conducted on an intention-to-treat basis

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group showed a significant improvement in OSATS scores, with a median score of 26.5 (interquartile range: 24â€“29) compared to the control group

Funding.evidence: The study was supported by institutional resources
